name: Alex Sangha
excerpt: Alex Sangha is a pioneering Canadian social worker, clinical counsellor, and documentary filmmaker dedicated to advancing LGBTQ+ rights within the South Asian and Sikh communities. As the founder of Sher Vancouver, he has created vital support networks for queer South Asians, earning national recognition including the Meritorious Service Medal for his advocacy and cultural bridge-building efforts.

biographySections.label: Early Life
biographySections.value: Alex Sangha, born Amar Singh Sangha, entered the world in Gravesend, Kent, England, to Sikh parents from Punjab, India‚Äîfather Dalbir Singh Sangha and mother Jaspal Kaur Sangha. His family immigrated to Canada, where he was primarily raised by his mother in the metro Vancouver area, specifically in Surrey and North Delta, British Columbia. Growing up in a devout Sikh household, Sangha experienced a culturally rich yet challenging environment as a South Asian immigrant child. He has two brothers (an older and younger) and a half-brother from his father's second marriage. As a teenager, Sangha grappled with his sexual orientation, describing his coming-out experience as deeply alienating and isolating, compounded by internalized homophobia within the conservative South Asian community. This personal struggle profoundly shaped his future advocacy work. He completed high school at Frank Hurt Secondary in Surrey and pursued higher education, earning an Associate of Arts from Douglas College in New Westminster, BC.

biographySections.label: Contributions/Service
biographySections.value: Sangha's career spans social work, counseling, and filmmaking, all centered on supporting marginalized communities, particularly LGBTQ+ individuals of South Asian descent. In April 2008, he founded Sher Vancouver as an online Yahoo group, which evolved into a registered charity providing peer support, education, and resources for lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer, and intersex (LGBTQI+) South Asians and allies. Under his leadership, Sher Vancouver became a cornerstone for queer Sikhs, offering safe spaces and combating stigma. As a Registered Clinical Social Worker and Registered Clinical Counsellor, Sangha maintains a private practice in North Delta, BC, where he provides therapy focused on mental health, trauma, and identity issues. Previously, he worked as an instructor, clinician, social worker, team leader, and youth counselor in various settings. In 2016, he personally supported a disowned Sikh international student from Punjab, integrating him into his family network. Sangha's documentary work amplifies these voices: his short film *My Name Was January* (citationNeeded ‚Äì production year) won 14 awards and 66 festival selections worldwide, while his feature debut *Emergence: Out of the Shadows* (premiered circa 2020) earned Best Documentary at festivals like the Vancouver International South Asian Film Festival and was selected for major events including Frameline and KASHISH Mumbai.

biographySections.label: Key Reforms
biographySections.value: Sangha has been instrumental in reforming attitudes toward LGBTQ+ inclusion within Sikh and South Asian communities, traditionally conservative on issues of sexuality. Through Sher Vancouver, he promoted family acceptance programs, culminating in his mother's 2018 speech on embracing her gay son, which received a standing ovation and symbolized shifting generational norms. As the first Sikh Grand Marshal of the Vancouver Pride Parade (citationNeeded ‚Äì exact year), he broke barriers for religious minorities in queer spaces. His advocacy extends to mental health, sharing his experiences with bipolar disorder in a 2020 commentary for the London School of Economics Alumni, framing it as a source of creative humanitarianism. In May 2020, he published a piece in *The Times of India* detailing a transformative "spiritual experience" at age 19 that reconciled his Sikh faith with his identity, influencing his career in social justice.

biographySections.label: Compositions/Writings
biographySections.value:
While not a traditional composer, Sangha's writings include opinion pieces and commentaries that blend personal narrative with advocacy. Key works:  
  - "Blessed with Bipolar" (2020, London School of Economics Alumni publication), exploring mental health as a strength in activism.  
  - Untitled commentary on spiritual awakening and sexuality (May 2020, *The Times of India*), reflecting on a pivotal experience in his youth that informed his work as a gay Punjabi Sikh activist.  
  His documentaries serve as visual "writings," documenting untold stories of queer South Asians.

biographySections.label: Final Years
biographySections.value: As of 2024, Sangha continues his multifaceted career in North Delta, BC, expanding Sher Vancouver's reach and producing content to foster dialogue on intersectional identities. He received the Courage to Come Back Award from Coast Mental Health (citationNeeded ‚Äì exact year, possibly 2020) for resilience in recovery and service. In 2018, he was awarded the Meritorious Service Medal by Governor General Julie Payette for founding Sher Vancouver, highlighting his enduring impact. His work persists amid ongoing challenges like community backlash and global pandemics, with recent focus on international student support and film distribution.

spiritualLegacy.description: As a devout Sikh, Alex Sangha embodies the Gurus' teachings of equality (sarbatt), compassion (daya), and justice (nyay), adapting them to modern contexts of sexual orientation and cultural identity. His efforts bridge Sikh spirituality with LGBTQ+ rights, promoting *seva* (selfless service) through inclusive community building.
keyContributions: Founded Sher Vancouver to create spiritually affirming spaces for queer Sikhs, aligning with Guru Nanak's rejection of discrimination.
Personal testimonies, like his 2020 *Times of India* piece, illustrate how Sikh principles aided his self-acceptance, inspiring others to reconcile faith and sexuality.
Advocacy for family reconciliation, exemplified by his mother's public support, reinforces Sikh values of familial unity and forgiveness.

modernRelevance.description: In the 21st-century Sikh diaspora, Sangha's work addresses the intersection of colonialism's lingering effects on gender norms, immigration stresses, and rising visibility of queer identities. His activism is vital in multicultural Canada, where South Asian communities navigate homophobia alongside racism.
contemporaryImpact: Empowers global queer South Asians via Sher Vancouver's online resources, influencing similar organizations worldwide.
Films like *Emergence: Out of the Shadows* raise awareness at international festivals, fostering empathy and policy changes for LGBTQ+ inclusion in religious spaces.
Mental health advocacy, including bipolar disclosure, destigmatizes disabilities within high-achieving immigrant communities.

historicalContext.politicalSituation: Post-1984 anti-Sikh violence in India and 9/11 Islamophobia affected Sikh immigrants in Canada; progressive LGBTQ+ policies (e.g., same-sex marriage legalization in 2005) contrasted with cultural conservatism in diasporic communities.
historicalContext.socialConditions: Rapid growth of South Asian diaspora in British Columbia (Vancouver as a hub); intersectional challenges for queer Sikhs included familial rejection, mental health stigma, and lack of culturally sensitive resources amid rising HIV/AIDS awareness in the 1990s‚Äì2000s.
historicalContext.significance: Sangha's work represents a pivotal shift toward inclusivity in Sikhism, aligning with global human rights movements and amplifying underrepresented voices in the post-colonial narrative of South Asian identity.
